metadata.title: Aminophosphine—rhodium complexes as catalysts in asymmetric hydrogenation. The influence of the chiral amino groups on the catalyst enantioselectivity.

THE INFLUENCE OF THE CHIRAL AMINO GROUPS ON TIE CATALYST ENANTIOSELEC`PIVI'IY. M_ FIORINI and G_ M_ GIONGO* Assoreri, Laboratorf Processi Microbfologici, 00015 Monterotondo, Rome (Italy) (Received May 21. 1979) In the course of our studies on the behaviour of a number of rhodiumbisaminopilosphine complexes as catalysts for the asymmetric hydrogenation of prochiral olefins [1], we have observed that both the catalyst enantioselectivity and the configuration of the reduction products are markedly dependent on the nature of the amino groups bound to the phosphorus atom. This is well evidenced (see Table 1) by the different bebaviout of the rhodium catalysts based on ligands PNNP(1) and (2) in the hydrogenation of a-acetaminoacrylic acid (4), a-acetaminocinnamic acid (5) and itaconic aci.d (6). X PH N ""-PPh,, (S, S)(-) PNNP(i), X-= H T~' PPh, (S, S)(-) PNNP(2), X = CH3 Ph - N-'~ X It was then hypothesized that this could be due, at least in part, to the influence of the two chiral non-racemic amino groups on the stereodifferentiating properties of the catalyst as a whole. To obtain further evidence in regard to this, we have prepared a closely related Iigand in which the amino groups are replace by two aohiral methylene uniEs, according to the following scheme [2 - 5] *To whom correspondence should be addressed- 412 - . . R . . 3 (4) PCCP(3) 1 +40.6 61.0 - R 4 (5) PNNP(1) 1 +43.9 93.8*=* S 5 (5) PNNP(2) 5 -32.0 68.4 R 6 (5) PCCP(3) 1 -25_3 54.0 R 7 (6)* PNNP(1) 1 +122 71_41- R 8 (6)* PNNP(2) 5 -1_0 5.8 S 9 (6)* PCCP(3) 1 -4.1 24_O S Solvent EtOH; Rh = 2.5mM; substrate/Rh = 125; temperature 25 C. *Rh = 7.3mM; substrate/Rh = 50_ **N-acetyl (R) alanine= [a]ps =+g6.5 (c = 2, Hz0). ***Nacetyl (S) phenylalanine= [a]DS = +46.8 (c = 1_08, EtOH). tR-methylsuacinic acid= [a]DS = +17.1 (c = 10, EtOH)_ Ph COJH Ph CHzOTs Ph CHZPPhZ i) i:) iv) iii) T= Ph = COON Ph = CH20Ts Ph - C1sZPPh2 (2S, 3g) S, S(+) PCCP(3) i) CHZNZ; ii) LLAIH49 iii) TsCl; iv) PhZPNa. The bisphosphine [3] [m.p. 140 - 141 C, [a] p = +81.8 (c = 1.6, CGHs); C = 81.8290 (calc. 83.04%), H = 6.1790 (calc. 6.2290)] has been used in the synthesis of the corresponding cationic rhodium complex according to known methods [6 ] . The catalytic hydrogenation runs (Table 1) coned that the `net' enantioselectivity-due to the chiral carbon atoms in PCCP(3) is substantially lower than that of the analogous PNNP-Rh catalysts. Both the higher e.e. values which are obtained with PNNP(1)-Rh and the inversion of configuration which occurs on going from PNNP(1) to PNNP(2) (and PCCP(3)), suggest that the second amino groups behave as additional binding sites for the incoming substrate (e.g.; hydrogen bonding), thus favouring a tighter coordination of the preferred enantioface of the olefin to the metal. Moreover, on comparing PCCP(3) with other chelating bisphosphines such as the Kagans DTOP and related analogues [7] , it appears that the latter are more effective as asymmetric induction agents, thus indicating that the chiral distortion and ring rigidity features, which in the DIOP group 413 mainly depend on.the strain imparted by the .cyclic substituents bound to the chiral centers, are more.proaotmO Ossh respect io those arising, as in. PCCP(3), from the mutual steric hindrance between the -ricinal aryl substituents. References I M. Fioriniand G. M. Giongo, J- Mol. Vatad., 5 (1979) 303. 2 H. Wren and J. Still. J Chem.
